title: The Amazing Race Australia: Muslim mother-daughter team Rowah and Amani hope to empower all women
text:
Muslim mother-daughter Rowah and Amani are set to bring the heat on The Amazing Race.

And the Sydney-based duo said they hope their journey around the world on the show empowers and inspires all women to get out of their comfort zone.

Rowah, 42, told Ten Daily: 'We are really hoping to empower women - and not just our fellow Muslim women - but women in general.'

'We hope to empower all women!' Muslim mother-daughter team Rowah (left) and Amani (right) want to inspire ladies to get out of their comfort zone ahead of The Amazing Race Australia premiere this Monday

'I want to encourage them to get out of their comfort zone and just do something different while you are still capable.'

Daughter Amani, 18, said the race pushed her to do things she never thought she was capable of doing.

'I surprised myself, to be honest, I think we both did - I'm really proud of us,' she added.

'I'm really proud of us': Amani added that the race pushed her to doing things she never thought she was capable of doing

This comes after NSW contestants Tim, 29, and Rod, 28, who are openly gay and newly married couple, praised the diverse casting for the reality show reboot.

Teams in the race include: 'Bondi influencers' Sid and Ash, NSW nurses Nick and Femi, and South Australian farmer Chris and his firefighter partner Adrienne.

Also in the race are Indigenous couple Jasmin and Jerome, brother-and-sister duo Alana and Niko, Queensland sisters Hayley and Mikayla, ACT nuns Judy and Therese, and footy mates Tom and Tyler.

Diversity: This comes after NSW contestants Tim, 29, and Rod, 28, (pictured) who are openly gay and newly married couple, praised the diverse casting on the show

The competition: Also in the race are Indigenous couple Jasmin and Jerome (left) and ACT nuns Judy and Therese (right)

The show's host Beau Ryan recently told The Daily Telegraph this season will be better than ever.

'What makes this show unique is the fact that anyone can take part in the race and anyone can win,' he said.

The show will see 11 teams race across three continents in a bid to win $250,000.

The Amazing Race Australia premieres Monday at 7.30pm on Channel 10
description: Muslim mother-daughter Rowah and Amani are set to bring the heat on The Amazing Race.
authors: Alisha Buaya For Daily Mail Australia
